clean_story:
"Unspoken pauses. Speech’s hidden rhythm. "

The phrase "silence in speech" refers to moments when no words are spoken—but meaning still flows.

Think of it like the space between musical notes.
Without it, lyrics blur into noise.

Silence isn’t just absence—it’s a tool.
A 2013 study found pauses of 0. 5–1. 5 seconds make listeners perceive a speaker as more confident.
Too short, and words rush.
Too long, and attention drifts.
In debates, silence can force an opponent to fill the gap—revealing weakness.
In therapy, it invites reflection.
Even in code, "null" (a programmed silence) holds data structures together.
Three related subjects are nonverbal cues, listening gaps, and sound’s negative space.
